APL Reform Committee to Address Trustees
The Committee for APL (the Applied Physics Laboratory) will hold a meeting this evening "to formulate proposals which will be sent to the Board of Trustees."
The meeting will be held at 7:30 in the Great Hall of
Levering.
The Committee has been formed by Hopkins' students
in an attempt to shift emphasis at the laboratory complex
away from military research toward more socially beneficial work. John Adams, co-organizer of the Committee stated that such questions as transportation research
and social analysis are far more important than military
research in today's world where the quality of researchers
such as those at APL area.
Jim Keogh indicated that a formal list of proposals
must be formulated immediately "because the issues
have had enough exposure and the people need concrete
issues now." "

"(Monistic Procedures"

Jim Keogh, co-organizer of the Committee for APL, wants
to bypass the "onanistic procedures" of the University.

Once the Committee's proposals have been outlined,
they will be presented directly to the Board of Trustees.
"To go through the onanistic procedures(of the University)
could only be an act of politeness to President Gordon,"
said Keogh. "And in view of Dr. Gordon's past service to
the militaristic mandarins that we're so concerned with,
such difference is uncalled for."
Keogh explained that he feels Gordon tobe 'irrelevant'

to the decision-making process at Hopkins. "We're confident that the Board of Trustees wants to make up its
own mind."
In addition to petitioning the Board of Trustees in hopes
of affecting some change in APL's research standards,
the Committee will hold a petition compaign to rally student and faculty support. Keogh noted that they also will
seek support from state-wide groups, such as the Maryland Moratorium Committee and SANE.

Areas Of Agreement
Keogh stated that this evening's meeting should "represent a broad cross section of the University's community."
He hopes to find what specific areas of agreement exist.
Despite uncertainities over the specific proposals which
will emerge from this evenings meeting, Keogh expects
a "low-key" campaign. "That doesn't mean however that
we want to get bogged down," he added."We're sure that
the Trustees will listen to reason."
The Committee will ask the Trustees to respond shortly
after Easter. "This will give them sufficient time to consider what we've said," he continued.
To date, the workshops sponsored by the Committee
for APL have been sporatically attenued. Nevertheless
Keogh has found them "very useful." He has been in contact with people from the Applied Physics Laboratory in
addition to his Committee's work at Homewood.

The Eclipse, Assateague, and Boy Scouts;
Nature Triumphs Over the Pseudo-Scientist
By MICHAEL HILL
Freaks and Boy Scouts alike gathered
in droves Saturday to view "the eclipse
of the century" which cut a swath of darkness up the eastern coast of the United
States.
In Maryland, the eclipse was total in
Ocean City and on Assateague Island.
Other popular gathering spots for people
from the Baltimore area were the Virginia portion of Assateauge, and the
coast south to Norfolk and Virginia
Beach.
Crowds of thousands began arriving
on Assateague early Saturday morning,
some drawn by the added attraction of
viewing a multitude of missle launchings from nearby Wallops Island. Most
of the probes were for atmospheric
measurements
connected
with
the
eclipse.
The population at Assateague was
mainly of the Boy Scout variety; both
young and old, all seemed to share the
motto "Be Prepared." Extensive warn-

ings about possible eye damage from
looking directly at the sun, which flooded the media for two days before the
eclipse, caused many watchers to construct complex viewing apparati.
In many cases these devices were
simply two pieces of cardboard, one
with a pinhole in it which focused an
image of the sun on the second piece. But
in some instances, telescopes were used
to project a large image onto a viewing
area of white paper. Crowds gathered
at the best of these.
In addition, nearly everyone had their
form of exposed photographic film or
smoked glass which was used for looking directly at the sun. Cameras abounded, some hooked to elaborate viewing rigs in hopes of getting a better
image.
All in all, most viewers, especially
those of the Boy Scout variety, were
showing their scientific or pseudoscientific side. Everyone wanted to display a greater degree of preparedness
than his neighbor, resulting in the long

wait for totality becoming almost like a
carnival, as one went from one booth to
the next, viewing and appraising the setup in each.
People came stocked with food and
beverage, some actually setting up useless tents for the few afternoon hours
they spent on the beach. But most of all,
they brought children, all showing the
same pseudo-scientific methods, and all
brought by their parents so that they
could tell their grandchildren that they
were there.
When the eclipse came, these people
literally did not know what to do. All of
their preparation had not prepared them
for this. An hour of waiting as the moon
slowly blocked more and more of the sun
from view was duly tracked and recorded by the Assateague scientists who remarked as to how it was getting darker
and colder. But suddenly, there it was.
Shadows running across the ground made
it seem as if the earth itself were drawing in its breath for what was about to
happen. A seemingly endless stream of

It was impossible to tell how long it
lasted, but as suddenly as it began it

cold but a few minutes before now
seemed quite light and warm.

By CHRISTOPHER OLANDER

TUESDAY

"American television," writes Alexander Kendrick," is now in its third decade as a mass broadcasting instrument. What is missing from its programming today is the vital ingredient of yesterday, its promise." One has only to turn on his set
tonight to realize the truth of Kendrick's statement. Like many products of technology, what began as a promising instrument for enlightenment
and fine entertainment has become what a recent
F.C.C. commissioner calls, "a vast wasteland."
Among the many reasons for this, three are dominant, corporatism, commercialism and apathy.
In television's infancy, like radio's, many in
the new field and in government viewed it as a
kind of a super-utility. It was to exist as a public
medium. For this reason the industry is theoretically controlled by a government agency which,
before granting its license to print money, demands that the local station present a minimum of
public service. Corporatism limits this. N.B.C.,
generally considered the largest network,is owned
by the Radio Corporation of America and itself
owns a major publishing house in addition to the
five local stations which the networks are allowed
to own.
C.B.S. owns the New York Yankees, two publishing houses, their own five stations and a host
of companies that manufacture everything from
toys to missiles. One need not imagine a conspiracy to realize that an industry dominanted by or
inextricably a part of another is subject to influences not directly concerned with its own perform ance.

Test Files
The proposed Honor Commission test files should be
completed and opened for use as soon as possible. It is
unfortunate that the files have not been made available
before this time. They should certainly be complete before this semester's finals period.
Honor Commission members claim that the files
would be complete were faculty members quicker to
supply copies of their back tests. It appears that the meager
response from professors is not due to faculty opposition
to establishing the file. It is simply a problem of convincing professors to respect a request made by undergraduates.
There has never-been a marked willingness to notice
undergraduates at Homewood, much less to act quickly
for their benefit. The Honor'Commission cannot hope to
compile an accurate file in the near future if it relies on
speedy action from the faculty.
Presumably the file is being created in response to
the charge that fraternity members have an unfair advantage in access to the files of their houses. The Honor
Commission is acting wisely when it attempts to eliminate
this advantage. By trying to build the Hutzler Reading
file from scratch, however, the Commission is negating
any benefits which might be derived from its good intentions. It seems more logical to turn to those whose files
are the most complete—the fraternities.

Good Rating
The sick state of television programming is
primarily caused by commercialism. Herbert
Hoover realized, decades ago, that if radio were
to be dominated by business, through advertizing,
the potential of the medium would be crippled.
Television is not comparable to radio, however,
and its potential as a marketplace was immediately recognized. But what began as an industry
using commercial revenue to support programming quickly became one in which the shows were
subservient to and dependent upon their particular
sponsors.
Today's situation is one by which a program
either attains a good rating(thus proving its ability
to sell a product by its popularity) or it is cancelled. It is absurd to be angered by the frequency
of commercial interruption in view of the fact that
the commercial is the goal, not what is sandwiched in between.
The industry's reply to "vast wasteland"
charges has always been that the public gets what
it wants. By this theory a show like "Petticoat
Junction" is aired, found to be popular, retains
the support of its sponsor and is retained by the
network. Since the public has voiced its approval,
on what grounds can anyone complain?
It might be argued, then, that if the publishing
industry produced only comic books and the public
liked many of them, why should it publish books.
It is the ability of the television industry to create
good taste (or at least stay abreast of public standards)that is being so ruthlessly abused.

Many of the houses have excellent files, and if the
resources of all the -houses were pooled, a fairly complete
file would probably result. At that point, the Commission
might apply directly to those faculty members whose tests
are not contained in the fraternity files. If the Commissior.r
acquired all of the fraternity files, the advantage which
has accrued to brothers will be eliminated immediately. At
that point, the Commission can worry about filling in the
gaps.

Intimate Relationship

In this way, any unfair advantage could be eliminated
and a substantial file opened for students more than one
month before finals begin. If the Honor Commission continues to leave it up to the faculty, however, it could well
be next spring before the files are made available.

Contrary to grim expectations, the denouement of They
Shoot Horses, Don't They? is more humane thandepressing. A cross-section of well chosen actors and actresses
Portrays those desparate souls of the thirties who brought
all their hopes to the dance marathon,which promised the
couple who outlasted the others a tempting little prize
Package of money. The others danced until they quite literally dropped. Jane Fonda is a very convincing contestant
named Gloria, whose familiarity with bad luck is
immediately apparent when ther ailing partner almost
disqualifies her from even entering the contest. She
quickly adopts another loner, however, who "has nothing
better to do."
By the time we've been through the grueling ordeal of
the dance marathon with Gloria we can do little else but
hope that her partner does in fact oblige her in this one
kind favor of blowing her tormented brains out. The natural
Protrusion of Jane Fonda's jaw, her steady disinterested
eyes, and her rapid manner of speech complete with builtin sarcasm are all more than adequate accessories for the
believability of hard-as-nails-born -loser Gloria, whose
history of hard knocks has nurtured the bitterness that
Will keep her going through most of the senseless masochistic marathon. Although her history is not fully outlined to us, we get the point.
Robert, her youthful partner, seems to be somewhat of
an ineffectual character who reminds one of a sad but
'obedient puppy dog (doleful brown eyes and all). Early he

learns that making conversation with Gloria is a blind
alley filled with caustic retorts. The romantics of the audlence are tempted to find some trace of a relationship
blossoming from the hours and hours of holding onto each
other that the contest requires,but Gloria does a good job
of thwarting even the most creative of imaginations in
that folly.
Some might pose this as possible criteria for romanticizing: that she does shed Robert apparently out of disappointment in his better judgment when after one of the
breaks she sees him emerge from the recesses of the
dance hall with vacuous pretty Alice, the budding starlet
played by Susannah York. Alice's participation in the marathon seems to be a stepping stone for her big break in a
somewhat questionable rise to fame.
True to puppy dog form, Robert obeys Alice's sexual
plea, which we surmise she asks to reassure herself that
she is still desirable after having sweated over her makeup, hair-style, and very impractical gown. Robert,as does
the audience, sees through the superficiality into the pathos
of her situation. Gloria does not.She finds Alice an insufferable sissy. Gloria in fact finds most of the other women
insufferable in one way or another, although she has moments of something akin to daughterliness to a grandmotherly spectator who sponsors her and Robert as they are
her "favorite couple."
By the time her second partner walks out on her, the
allegory intended is becoming painfully obvious. Gloria

dances along for awhile and finally ends upwith Red Buttons, the salty sailor who has been headed for a very predictable heart attack for the entire duration of the movie.
The ruthless ten-minute derby in which everybody wins but
the last three couples provides the final clincher for the
probability of the occurrence of his heart attack.

incurred by the winners during their stay onthe premises,
she denounces it all with a long-awaited "What's the

following letter:

it all straight. The main thing, I suppose,

sexual intercourse. I did it with a friend
of mine from school. I think I liked it, but
I am not sure. Recently, there has been

a spate of such actions by my schoolmates, and the authorities are up in arms.

sentenced to five years in jail for what
you call 'making love'.(What a wonderfully strange expression! Someday you
must explain to me what 'love' means).

Caught in the Act
This growing problem among people
my age has been the subject of a speech
by our principal. He argues that in this
important and crucial period of our island's development, any activity which
takes people away from reality is highly
dangerous. Screwing disorients people
for up to several hours and, in some
cases, weeks or months. It serves no
constructive function, merely taking people away from important activities such
as their work. Though there is no evidence, he says, that screwing is physically harmful or physically addictive,there
is strong evidence that it is psychologically addictive: people who do it
tend to want to do it again. Moreover, it

tends to distort perception. When one has
had sexual relations with another person
one tends not to look at him or her in the
normal way, i.e., in the way one looks
at other objects in the world like books or
machines. This is highly dangerous to the
structure of our society. Our principal
proposes harsher penalties for anyone
caught in the forbidden act.

Society's Standards
These arguments bother me a great
deal. I see their force, but something in
their whole outlook bothers me, though I
can't put my finger on it. One of our deans
is a very liberal man, popular with many
of the students. He agrees that screwing
may be no more dangerous than other acts
sanctioned by our state, such as the headhunting which goes on every April. But

however, that since so many young people
are experimenting with this act, we
should not penalize them, especially as
they are likely to come to their senses

later on. He thinks the laws should be
made less harsh for people caught in the

behavior on others, or who engage in it
repeatedly, should be punished more
severely than the casual screwer. "We
are after the big guys," he says.
What makes the situation even more
difficult is that many of the ‘screwers',
as they are called, seem to be mentally
unbalanced, at least from the point of view
of society. They claim that society's
standards are at fault, but I don't know.
I am very confused. When I tried it, I felt
some things which I think were good, but
I can't describe them. There is talk of
putting television cameras in bedrooms
if things get any worse. This seems reasonable to many--especially those who
are scared. To me it seems a bit extreme.
Am I on to something, or should I just
get back to my study of insemination
techniques?
Yours,

of Athletics or the University administration. Last year the swimmers faced a similar situation in going to the NCAA's at Springfield

than last year's trip because of the distance and number of swimmers
involved. Those making the trip planto leave Tuesday night and spend

year either. Having reached such a high calibre of excellence they deserve better.

is over $900. So far the swimmers themselves have raised $300
through their life-guarding activities, $200 from the H-Club ($150)
and the Booster Club ($50), and $25 from TEP. The remaining $400
can come from a number of sources.

class president to donate $100. If this doesn't work, the fraternities
could be asked to give some money. The IFC could also donate at
least $100. Assuming these sources fail to reach the $900-plus goal,
then alumni and friends of the swimming team might be asked to donate
something. This last figure is the most variable of all and is the
hardest to estimate accurately.

students and not the university are expected to shell out the difference. The university-wide cry for money is met with increases in tuition and the student activities fee. Such a policy is shortsighted, for

present policy wilrliacIdire.

charging admission to football and basketball home games.This money
should go to finance the trips, and in seasons when the admissions'

university should step in and subsidize them.

liked many of them, why should it publish books.

Contrary to grim expectations, the denouement of They
Shoot Horses, Don't They? is more humane thandepressing. A cross-section of well chosen actors and actresses
Portrays those desparate souls of the thirties who brought
all their hopes to the dance marathon,which promised the
couple who outlasted the others a tempting little prize
Package of money. The others danced until they quite literally dropped. Jane Fonda is a very convincing contestant
named Gloria, whose familiarity with bad luck is
immediately apparent when ther ailing partner almost
disqualifies her from even entering the contest. She
quickly adopts another loner, however, who "has nothing
better to do."
By the time we've been through the grueling ordeal of
the dance marathon with Gloria we can do little else but
hope that her partner does in fact oblige her in this one
kind favor of blowing her tormented brains out. The natural
Protrusion of Jane Fonda's jaw, her steady disinterested
eyes, and her rapid manner of speech complete with builtin sarcasm are all more than adequate accessories for the
believability of hard-as-nails-born -loser Gloria, whose
history of hard knocks has nurtured the bitterness that
Will keep her going through most of the senseless masochistic marathon. Although her history is not fully outlined to us, we get the point.
Robert, her youthful partner, seems to be somewhat of
an ineffectual character who reminds one of a sad but
'obedient puppy dog (doleful brown eyes and all). Early he

learns that making conversation with Gloria is a blind
alley filled with caustic retorts. The romantics of the audlence are tempted to find some trace of a relationship
blossoming from the hours and hours of holding onto each
other that the contest requires,but Gloria does a good job
of thwarting even the most creative of imaginations in
that folly.
Some might pose this as possible criteria for romanticizing: that she does shed Robert apparently out of disappointment in his better judgment when after one of the
breaks she sees him emerge from the recesses of the
dance hall with vacuous pretty Alice, the budding starlet
played by Susannah York. Alice's participation in the marathon seems to be a stepping stone for her big break in a
somewhat questionable rise to fame.
True to puppy dog form, Robert obeys Alice's sexual
plea, which we surmise she asks to reassure herself that
she is still desirable after having sweated over her makeup, hair-style, and very impractical gown. Robert,as does
the audience, sees through the superficiality into the pathos
of her situation. Gloria does not.She finds Alice an insufferable sissy. Gloria in fact finds most of the other women
insufferable in one way or another, although she has moments of something akin to daughterliness to a grandmotherly spectator who sponsors her and Robert as they are
her "favorite couple."
By the time her second partner walks out on her, the
allegory intended is becoming painfully obvious. Gloria

dances along for awhile and finally ends upwith Red Buttons, the salty sailor who has been headed for a very predictable heart attack for the entire duration of the movie.

the last three couples provides the final clincher for the
probability of the occurrence of his heart attack.

incurred by the winners during their stay onthe premises,
she denounces it all with a long-awaited "What's the
point?". We breathe a sign of relief for her and her feet,
and are grateful to Robert for putting her out of her misery.

Experts Confer with Students on Foreign Policy

By RALPH MOLLER
Henry Kissinger, Special Adviser on
Foreign Affairs to President Nixon, will
be one of the featured speakers at a student conference on United States Foreign
Policy to be held at the Johns Hopkins
School of Advanced International Studies
in Washington, D.C.
The conference, part of the observance
of the twenty-fifth anniversary of SAIS,
will be held on April 16, 17 and 18. Twenty
eight of the leading graduate schools in
international relations have been invited
to send two student representatives to the
conference.
Among the schools invited are Harvard,
Princeton, the University of California
at Los Angeles, the University of Michigan, and Cornell.

Four Areas
These four areas will be introduced in
four plenary sessions.In each session two
papers which have been previously assigned to different schools and distributed to all members of the conferencewill
be summarized. Each will cover a different aspect of the assigned topic.
FolloWing the presentation of the
papers, a panel discussion will be held.
The members of each panel will include
two student representatives and two
"professional's"---academic, government, business and news media representatives with experience in foreign
affairs. These panels will criticize and
evaluate the arguments presented in the
papers.
